data.name: label1.Text
data.value: The nervous system, along with the endocrine system, regulates most of the body’s functions. The nervous system (NS) has a particular role in regulating the activity of the muscles and secretory glands (both exocrine and endocrine), while the endocrine system mainly regulates metabolic functions. The Regulation of skeletal muscle activity is performed by somatic NS, and the Regulation of the activity of visceral muscles and glands (exo- and endocrine) is performed by vegetative NS. Between the NS and the endocrine system there is a close interdependence. The human body is a cybernetic system. The concept of a system is very comprehensive: A system is any set of elements in uncoincidental interaction. According to this definition, every living organism is a system, just as every apparatus or machine is a system, society is also a system, the atom also, etc. the boundary between systems is not absolute. Each system, in turn, is a component of more complex systems and at the same time contains several subsystems. Some systems evolve according to the second principle of disorder thermodynamics (with increasing entropy of the system); others oppose this increase or even reduce it. These are self-regulated systems or cyber systems. Every cyber system has at least two major components: Command and Control Center (C) and execution device (E). To develop appropriate commands, the center must receive information on the variations in the adjusted parameter and how the commands are executed. The return path of information from the effector to the center is called feedback circuit, recurrent information, or reverse connection. All self-Regulation mechanisms work on feedback. In order for the recurrent information to be as accurate as possible, the feedback adjustment mechanism has a system of transducers (T) (or receptors) that senses both the initial disturbance (P) and the accuracy of the correction made by the effector on the regulated element (ER). By feedback, the adjusted parameter influences the center of adjustment. Thus, the feedback mechanism works according to its effects.but in collaboration; any Regulation is actually neuro-humoral. Command and control centers are located in the central nervous system and endocrine system, for nervous and humoral Regulation. At the same time, all endocrine activity is coordinated by the central nervous system, via the hypothalamusultu. At this level, the integration of nervous and humoral Regulation takes place. A second point of fusion between the nervous and humoral mechanisms is found at the level of peripheral effectors, whose function is influenced by chemical messengers; these chemical messengers can be hormones (in the case of humoral Regulation) or chemical mediators released by nerve endings (in the case of nerve Regulation).
